div.p: Four copies of Songs of Experience, printed by Blake independent of Songs of Innocence, are now extant, although their letter designations are part of the sequence of the combined Songs of Innocence and of Experience. Copies G and H, consisting of 17 plates (28-33, 37, 38, 40-43, 46, 47, 49-51), were produced in the first (1794) printing of Experience, along with what is now the “Experience” section of combined Songs Copy F and plates (designated copy T1) now integrated into combined Songs Copy T. These four copies were probably printed before Blake had etched four plates (39, 44, 45, 48) for Songs of Experience and were produced by him as complete Copies at the time of printing. Copies K and N (printed 1795) were once part of copies of the combined Songs (as their numbering in pen and ink indicates) but are now separate. Copy K was once bound with the “Innocence” section of Songs of Innocence and of Experience Copy O; Copy N may have been bound with untraced Copy W of Songs of Innocence. Two posthumous copies, k and l, contain only plates from Songs of Experience.
See also Songs of Innocence and of Experience
